problem.tex: Calculate the integral \[\int_\gamma\frac{dz}{z^2+\pi^2}\] where $\gamma(\theta)=\theta e^{i\theta}$ for $\theta\in(0,2\pi)$.

solution.tex: First, let's close $\gamma$ with the curve $c(t)=t$ for $t\in(0,2\pi)$. Then the concatenation $p$ of $\gamma$ with the reverse of $c$ $(p=\gamma-c)$ is a closed loop. The poles of $\frac{1}{z^2+\pi^2}$ occur at $\pm\pi i$, we need to check if these points are encircled by $p$. For all $\theta\in(0,2\pi), |\gamma(\theta)|=\theta$. Then $\pi i$ is not encircled but $-\pi i$ is. We apply the Cauchy integral formula to get \[\int_p\frac{\frac{1}{z-\pi i}}{z+\pi i}dz=2\pi i\left(\frac{1}{-\pi i-\pi i}\right)=-1.\] This helps because \[\int_pf(z)dz=\int_\gamma f(z)dz-\int_cf(z)dz.\] Therefore \[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\int_cf(z)dz-1.\] Now to compute the integral over $c$. Recall $c(t)=t$, so the integral parametrizes as \[\int_0^{2\pi}\frac{dt}{t^2+\pi^2}.\] This is an arctangent integral, the answer is $\frac{\arctan(2)}{\pi}$. Thus our desired integral is \[\int_\gamma\frac{dz}{z^2+\pi^2}=\frac{\arctan(2)}{\pi}-1.\]
